The car began shuddering and they emerged to find themselves driving on the wrong side of the road.When Wood and Wright arrived in the South Lanarkshire village of Tarbrax, where they were due to drop off a satellite TV system, they discovered that several hours were unaccounted for. Afterwards they underwent hypnosis sessions, with both men recalling an alien abduction scenario and being subjected to a medical-type examination.Dunfermline: Anglers unexpected catchA metallic disc-shaped craft was caught on camera as it hovered above Craigluscar Reservoir near Dunfermline, Fe, on February , .Ian Macpherson, a member of the local angling club and a keen artist, was taking photographs to assist with a painting he was working on. He was first alerted to something out of the ordinary by a humming noise, similar to that from high voltage power lines.Macpherson describes a sudden uneasy feeling as he turned towards the water to see the object coming towards him. He stood frozen, watching it for more than  minutes.According to his statement: "The craft came close enough for me to see that it was definitely metallic and had several points of dfused light on its underside, inside a darker coloured rim."It was only as the disc flew off at high speed that Macpherson felt able to raise his camera and take two photographs. He said: "The crafts acceleration was phenomenal ndash by the time Id wound the film on between the two shots, it was a mere dot in the sky."By his own admission, Macpherson had no interest in the subject of UFOs. Subsequent checks with the RAF, airports and the police, confirmed no known air traffic at the time.

title: 12-natural-wonders-scotland-must-visit-lifetime
story: Narrowing down a list of favourites was no easy task, but wersquove given it a bash, bringing together a mix of well-known spots and lesser-visited gems deserving of more column inches.If you are heading out to explore this weekend, herersquos some mesmerising and memorable locations courtesy of Mother Nature.Here are  natural wonders of Scotland:Eshaness, ShetlandYou can feel the raw power of nature pulsating from what has been described as one of the most high energy coastlines in the world. Battered by the colossal force of the North Atlantic, this corner of Shetland is home to caves, stacks, arches, blowholes and geos .The peninsula is formed from the remains of the extinct Eshaness volcano, dating back some  to  million years. The clfs you see today cut through the flank of the volcano, revealing layers of lava and pyroclastic rock blasted from its crater.Visit shetland.orgAn Lochan Uaine, Glenmore, near AviemoreThe emerald waters of An Lochan Uaine, aka The Green Lochan, in Glenmore Forest Park are an enchanting sight to behold. According to legend, the distinctive hue came about when pixies washed their clothes here.Scientic bods will tell you itrsquos more likely down to the algae generated by decomposing wood that lines the lochanrsquos floor or a fluke of the light reflecting off the trees around its edges. Pah, spoilsports. I mean, who do you believe  Keep your eyes peeled for pixies on the gentle walk through the ancient Caledonian pines.Visit forestryandland.gov.scotFingalrsquos Cave, StaffaThis mysterious sea cave on the uninhabited Hebridean island of Staffa looks intricately hand-carved rather than formed by a quirk of cooling lava. The ftcavern has tremendous acoustics.Fingalrsquos Cave gained its moniker from the eponymous hero of a poem by the th-century Scots poet-historian James Macpherson .Composer Felix Mendelssohn wrote an overture in its honour, artist J M W Turner has painted it and author Jules Verne mentions it in three novels, including the famed Journey to the Centre of the Earth.Visit staffatoursBow Fiddle Rock, near Portknockie, MorayTherersquos no big secret to how this incredible natural formation got its name: it looks uncannily like a bow perched atop the strings of a fiddle. Located just off the coast from Portknockie, the distinctive shape was forged over time as the force of the waves eroded a type of rock called Cullen Quartzite.It is a place that you can photograph a hundred times and each one captures something slightly dferent ndash be it the colour of the sky, the swell of the sea or a hint of brooding atmosphere. Bow Fiddle Rock forms part of the North East  route as it traverses the Moray Firth coastline.Visit northeast and visitscotlandFortingall Yew, PerthshireThe Fortingall Yew, pictured, found growing in the churchyard of the Perthshire village which shares its name, is among the oldest trees in Europe. There is some debate about its age. Modern experts estimate the tree is between , and , years old.Fortingall YewAccording to folklore, Pontius Pilate ndash the Roman governor who oversaw the crucixion of Jesus ndash was born in its shade and played there as a child. More recently this legend has been credited as a hoax devised by Sir Donald Currie, a shipping magnate who bought the Glenlyon Estate in .Visit visitscotlandOrkneyrsquos sea stacksThe rugged clfs and coastline around Orkney boast a raft of spectacular sea stacks with The Old Man of Hoy, a fthigh monolith of towering, red sandstone perhaps its most famous. That said, he it has many handsome siblings, such as The Needle on Hoyrsquos south-west coast.The Old Man of Hoy. Picture: Cameron McNeish Scottish Walks MagazineTherersquos the striking Yesnaby Castle on the west mainland, and North Gaulton Castle which the eagle-eyed may recognise from a  car advert for Rover. Further up the mainland coast, just north of the Bay of Skaill, therersquos the brilliantly named Stack orsquo Roo.Visit orkneyGalloway Forest Dark Sky Park, Dumfries and GallowayWhen did you last see the Milky Way  For those of us residing in urban areas, itrsquos more likely we are familiar with the sweet treat found in corner shops than the bright band arching across the night sky. Galloway Forest Park is a perfect spot to go stargazing.Very few people live within its  square miles area which means the nights are jet black. A clutch of planets and more than , twinkling stars are visible with the naked eye. The Perseid meteor shower reaches its peak from August  to  this year. Top tip: take a sun lounger because it saves on neck craning.Visit scottishdarkskyobservatory and forestryandland.gov.scotThe Cuillin, SkyeRed or black  Itrsquos almost impossible to choose, like being asked to pick a favourite child. The Cuillin is made up of two ranges ndash the Black Cuillin and the Red Cuillin ndash separated by Glen Sligachan.They were formed by volcanic and glacial activity, then further sculpted by weathering over the millennia to emerge looking very dferent indeed.The jagged outlines of the Black Cuillin are the remains of a magma chamber belonging to a giant volcano and comprised largely of rough gabbro rock, while the rounded humps of the Red Cuillin are made mainly of granite.Visit visitscotlandCorryvreckan Whirlpool, ArgyllA perilous, swirling vortex with a formidable reputation. The Corryvreckan Whirlpool, between Jura and Scarba, is infamous for strong tidal currents and standing waves that make it one of the most dangerous stretches within the British Isles. At times, the mighty roar is so loud that it can be heard  miles away. The whirlpool is the third-largest in the world and caused by an unusual underwater topography in the Gulf of Corryvreckan that creates the so-called speckled cauldron. There are boat tours available for those brave enough to venture here.Visit craignishcruises and juraboattoursGrey Marersquos Tail, Moffat, DumfriesshireTalk about a beautul image. Evenyou have never seen this thundering waterfall in the flesh, you can imagine what it looks like ndash the swishing grey tail of a mare ndash as it cascades down ftwhere the Tail Burn flows from Loch Skeen into the Moffat Water Valley.Grey Mares Tail. Picture: National Trust for ScotlandIts majesty was celebrated in verse by Sir Walter Scott who wrote in Marmion about the frothing water as being as ldquowhite as the snowy chargerrsquos tail. There is historical evidence in the nearby area of Iron Age settlers and the Covenanters who sought sanctuary in the th century.Visit nts.org.ukBass Rock, East LothianSure, itrsquos a big lump of rock covered in bird poo, but, in geological and natural history terms, the Bass Rock is a stunner. The steep-sided volcanic plug rises ftout of the Firth of Forth.It is regarded as a Site of Special Scientic Interest and is renowned for its vast gannet colony ndash some , at the peak of the breeding season ndash hailed by Sir David Attenborough as ldquoone of the  wildle wonders of the world.The Bass Rock has been a retreat for early Christian hermits, welcomed royal visits and served as a notorious gaol for religious and political prisoners.Visit seabird.orgThe beaches of Sanday, OrkneySanday by name, sandy by nature. Seen from the air you would be forgiven for imagining you had flown through a tear in the space-time continuum and were seeing a tropical island in the Caribbean or South Pacic rather than Scotland. Bays and beaches, white sands and turquoise waters abound.Among the many gems on Sanday is Tresness, a sliver of a peninsula with ine dunes sandwiched between a sheltered tidal bay to the west and the North Sea on the east. Therersquos also the gorgeous Whitemill Bay, Lopness, Sty Wick, Scuthvie Bay and Sandquoy ndash the list goes on.Visit orkney

title: musselburgh-dunbar-tranent-parents-find-day-child-returns-high-school
story: The soft start will mean all students will not be back in class full-time in East Lothian until Monday, August .At Musselburgh Grammar School, headteacher Colin Gerrie said S and S  students would be back on Wednesday, August , for a -to-school induction and timetables to be issued.On Thursday, August , it will be the turn of S  to attend for the induction and on Friday, August , S and S will be in school with S students back from period three onwards.On Monday, August , all Musselburgh Grammar School pupils willfull-time.Mr Gerrie said more details about what would be expected as schools resumed would be sent to parents on Friday.In a letter to parents and carers he said there were two reasons East Lothian schools had opted for the phasedndash ensuring the health and safety of all students and staff and supporting their wellbeing.He said: ldquoA phasedwill allow each year group to have an induction which will explain new systems to students and ensure they feel confident, secure and safe with theto school.ldquoWe believe that a phased , with an induction, will offer us the opportunity to re-connect with our students in a supportive and smaller scale setting.ldquoIt is also important that our new S students have the opportunity to have a transition experience.Dunbar Grammar School,Ross High School, Knox Academy and North Berwick High Schoolare following the same phasedpattern for their pupils.All four schools will welcome back S   pupils on Wednesday, August , for a -to-school induction and to collect timetables.On Thursday, August , S pupils will have a transition day at the schools, supported by Ss, which will include tours of the school and meeting staff.S son Friday, August , for the induction and collection of timetables and all pupils are expected to be back on Monday, August .Preston Lodge High School, Prestonpans, has not yet confirmed its phasedtimetable although it is expected to follow the same plan as the majority of the secondary schools.

title: easyjet-jet2-ryanair-tui-share-rules-children-wearing-face-masks
story: Families may now be heading abroad for a week or two in the sun during the summer holidays -with many getting used to wearing face masks when navigating their way through the airport and while on the plane.But do children have to wear face masks on flights  Herersquos what you need to know.Where do I need to wear a face mask Children under , those who cant wear a covering without suffering severe distress, or who have dficulty using one due to a physical or mental disability, are exempt from wearing face coverings.However, rules y when it comes to air travel, with dferent airlines having their own stipulations on the ages at which children need to wear a mask.Do children have to wear face masks on planes Airlines have dfering rules when it comes to children wearing masks.Easyjet said:ldquoIn line with the guidance, all passengers including children aged six and over will be required to wear a mask.However,you are unable to wear a face mask for medical reasons then you will be exempt from doing so.This is ldquoas long as you have a medical exemption letter from a doctor stating that you cannot wear a face maskand also that you are fit to fly.If you are flying with Ryanair, then children under  do not need to wear face masks.Again,you suffer from a medical condition that prevents you from wearing a face mask then ldquoyou are exempted from the face mask obligation on provision of a medical certicate attesting your condition.Jet states that ldquoeveryone needs to wear a face mask at all times while travelling, apart from children under six years old and people that canrsquot wear a mask for medical reasons.The current advice from British Airways says: ldquoWe require all customers to wear a face mask at all times in the airport and on board. As a guide, a face mask could last up to four hours, so please make sure that you bring enough for the duration of your trip.Travellers will also be asked to remove their face masks for any passport checks but will be advised to do so my members of staff.If travelling with TUI, then everyone over the age of six years old needs to wear a face mask during their flight.The tour operator asks that you bring your own masks, which you will need to change every four hours.However,you have a medical condition which exempts you from wearing a mask, then you wonrsquot need to.What are the exemptions Gov.uk explains that you do not need to wear a face coveringyou have a legitimate reason not to.This includes:What have the World Health Organisationsaid Wearing a face covering doesnrsquot mean that hygiene measures, and social distancing where possible, shouldnrsquot be carried out.The World Health Organisationexplains:ldquoMasks should be used as part of a comprehensive strategy of measures to suppress transmission and save lives the use of a mask alone is not sufficient to provide an adequate level of protection against Covid-.ldquoYou should also maintain a minimum physical distance of at least one metre from others, frequently clean your hands and avoid touching your face and mask.

title: lengthy-wait-gyms-swimming-pools-reopen-doors
story: The Scottish Government announced plans to relax coronavirus-related restrictions, which could see indoor sports facilities, including swimming pools, open their doors again on September .Enjoyleisure, which operates sports centres in Dunbar, Haddington, Musselburgh, North Berwick and Tranent, says it has already made ldquosignicant progress in preparing the facilities for reopening.Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, which employs  people, including relief colleagues, said it had been a dficult time, with sports centres having been closed for almost six months by the time they could reopen.A revenue shortfall of about pound. million is being predicted for this financial year, with  members of staff currently furloughed, with a number of others taken off furlough prior to the reopening of golf courses and outdoor pitch facilities.Mr Axon said: ldquoAs the local leisure charitable trust provider, we deliver essential services at an affordable and subsidised cost for all.ldquoWe dynamically contribute to the local economy, whilst generating social value across communities on account of improved personal and collective health, wellbeing, social cohesion, and decreased antisocial behaviour and crime.ldquoOur role will be even more important as we begin to recover as a community from the after effects of lockdown.ldquoLike other providers within the public charitable sector, enjoy has had many financial challenges to overcome over the years, which has not been easy.ldquoHowever due to pragmatic and sound decision making, with support from my board, staff and trade unions, enjoy has maintained a stable financial position.ldquoSince the Covid- lockdown on March , enjoyleisurersquos income levels have become non-existent.ldquoThe charity is currently predicting a revenue shortfall of circa pound. million for  .ldquoHowever, we have taken signicant actions that have gone some way to mitigating these losses.Measures are currently being put into place at sports centres ahead of the reopening date in a bid to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.Enjoyleisure said it was ldquocompletely redefining its cleaning and safety standards, while risk assessments are being updated.Physical distancing measures are also being introduced, including one-way systems, dedicated two-metre square workout areas within gyms and fitness studios while the number of lockers and changing cubicles available will also be reduced.New booking procedures will be introduced while staff will be retrained in the new safety and hygiene protocols and will be supplied with their own PPE.Mr Axon said they would need support to get back to ldquoa position of strength while requests have been made to the Government for emergency funding.He added: ldquoI am delighted that both Iain Gray MSP and Kenny MacAskill MP have provided their backing for enjoyrsquos request, as they acknowledge the real and substantial sporting, health, personal and collective wellbeing benefits from having a thriving, motivated and community supporting leisure trust within East Lothian.ldquoI have full confidence in enjoyrsquos ability to continue safely serving our communities, and provide the vital amenities, quality facilities and activities truly lsquoenjoyedrsquo by our patrons.ldquoI and everyone connected with enjoy are totally committed to maintaining these high standards for everyone who resides or visits East Lothian.Enjoyleisure also confirmed the summer seasonal facilities would not be reopening until .A spokeswoman for the group said: ldquoIn terms of the summer seasonal facilities, North Berwick putting greens, Fisherrow bowling green and pitch n putt these facilities will regrettably not be opening this year.ldquoDue to the nature of the pandemic and timescales provided, it would not have been financially viable to open these facilities this year.

title: welcome-return-beach-wheelchairs-restarts-north-berwick
story: The charity offers specially designed wheelchairs that allow people with disabilities or those who need to use a wheelchair the chance to enjoy East Lothianrsquos beaches.It temporarily closed its hut on March  in line with Government guidance at the time as the coronavirus lockdown got under way.An all-terrain power wheelchair, four manual wheelchairs, a beach walker and a hoist are on offer from the charity.All equipment is free to hire but those who wish to use the service are asked to book in advance by calling   , with volunteers then discussing what best suits an inidualrsquos needs.Beach Wheelchairs is following strict health and safety guidelines to keep its volunteers and customers safe.All equipment will be thoroughly cleaned between each use and each wheelchair will be left for at least  hours between each use.Volunteers will all be wearing masks and gloves.The power wheelchair will only be available to those who have used it previously this is because social distancing means providing safety training will be dficult to do from a two-metre distance.When using the hoist, people are asked to bring their own sling.People will have to move and store the wheelchair they hire themselves without the assistance of a volunteer and they are recommended to use the wheelchairs service at quieter times.It is recommended that two carers are in attendance unless people are confident that one carer can help with no physical assistance from a volunteer.Those who begin to experience symptoms of coronavirus after using one of the beach wheelchairs are asked to let volunteers know as soon as possible so that the chair can be removed from service for  hours.For more information, visit Beach Wheelchairs on Facebook.

title: knight-fever-dance-among-schools-making-plea-able-open
story: Pubs, restaurants, cafes and shops throughout the country have reopened their doors in recent weeks as the coronavirus lockdown has been eased.However, gyms, swimming pools and dance studios remain shut.Gemma Knight, from Knight Fever Dance, has joined more than  dance schools across Scotland in getting in touch with the Government asking for an update.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom on a chat on Facebook with more than  dance schools across Scotland.ldquoWe all feel a wee bit let down by the Government.ldquoWersquove never been recognised ndash it is either gyms or sports places ndash but dance studios have not been mentioned.Knight Fever Dance is based at Haddington Golf Club and was set up in August last year.Since then, the dance school has grown from  children to  youngsters.The dance school offers youngsters aged between three and  the chance to learn a iety of styles, including jazz, hip-hop, street dance, contemporary and more, as well as taking part in a number of competitions.Gemma, who is originally from Musselburgh but now lives in Haddington, has taught dancing across the county for more than a decade.She was keen to see the dance school reopened and said: ldquoIrsquove literally had so many parents asking lsquowhatrsquos going on rsquoldquoWersquore trying to gauge it with what is going on in England, where their studios opened on Monday.The dance school has linked up with similar facilities across the country to write to the Scottish Government.The letter states: ldquoThe majority of our businesses work with children ndash the lowest risk people in this pandemic.ldquoMany of our classes can be run contactlessor with minimal interaction physical distancing can be achieved and where we have studios of our own we can plan for systems and processes to allow us to resume business with increased hygiene, as is being considered in the sports industry.ldquoOur students are missing out greatly on the health and mental wellbeing benefits of attending our classes.ldquoMany of us would have put on summer workshops and camps, something that could have helped bridge the gap over the summer prior to starting school in August.ldquoIf outdoor lsquocontactrsquo sports for children can resume now then why arenrsquot indoor non-contact activities being considered now with adequate guidance and dates ldquoWhy are those sectors being favoured over ours ldquoChildren who engage in contact sports currently have routes to better physical and mental wellbeing but those children who prefer to engage in other non-contact physical activities are not being considered.The issue was raised during a coronavirus briefing with Scotlandrsquos First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and John Swinney MSP, Education Secretary, last Tuesday.Ms Sturgeon did not give a date for when dance schools could reopen but hoped to give guidance around safety measures as quickly as possible.She said: ldquoWe obviously want to see those who have been shielded get to live their lives more normally again and that central objective of getting schools back full time.ldquoThese are the absolute priorities.ldquoTherefore that does mean that we will take a very cautious approach to any further opening up right now.ldquoI know that is really dficult for people who are in the sectors that cannot open right now and we will try to give certainty as soon as we can and as much certainty as we can but we cannot do everything all at once or we will very quickly compromise our ability to do the things that I think most people accept are the priorities, which is to get young people back to school.

title: ready-take-off-museum-flight-reopens-doors
story: Visitors to the museum ndash which closed in March due to the coronavirus lockdown ndash need to book a time slot in advance. Tickets are available online.Until next Sunday , the museum will be free to enter.Concorde and the museumrsquos shop will open first, with hangars two and three reopening from next Monday .Several new measures have been introduced to ensure visitors have a safe visit.People are encouraged to keep a two-metre distance from others, use the hand sanitiser on-site, wash their hands, follow direction signs and pay for items using a card.Visitors are also asked to wear face coverings in indoor spaces and shops.National Museums Scotland also confirmed that two of its other venues are scheduled to reopen, the Museum of Rural Le on Wednesday and National Museum of Scotland on August . Opening of the National War Museum is still to be confirmed.

title: musselburgh-rugby-club-beer-garden-offers-safe-place
story: Members and guests were welcomed to the large outdoor space which has been created at its grounds at Stoneyhill.The beer garden and lsquoPickerings Patiorsquo ndash named after one of the clubrsquos main sponsors Pickerings Gin ndash is offering them a safe space to visit as the lockdown eases.A club spokesperson said: ldquoWe hope it will be a welcome facility for the local community and a permanent feature as the club moves into its centenary year in .ldquoThe club has done a lot of work getting familiar with all of the Covid government and council guidance, including full risk assessments and ensuring all staff have appropriate PPE.ldquoWe have installed sanitisers at key posts around the club and have an increased cleaning system for our toilet and bar facilities, as well as introducing systems in the bar and toilets which implement social distancing.The spokesperson added: ldquoWe really enjoyed welcoming back members and guests to our new outdoor space which we have worked hard to make sure is a safe area, given we have the luxury to use a lot of space outside the club.ldquoWe recognise peoplersquos levels of comfort will be very dferent coming outof lockdown and want to ensure we offer a safe place to visit, while also offering some form of normality, as the club has always been a welcoming and fun place to visit.ldquoThe staff have been doing a great job and we recognise it is still a learning curve for everyone, including guests.ldquoWe are looking to adapt to opening insidewe have to address any poor weather but this brings restrictions and will be thought out in more detail moving forward.The beer garden and Pickerings Patio is open Fridays pm-pm, Saturdays noon-pm and Sundays pm-pm.While walk-ins are welcome, subject to availability, bookings are recommended at the Eventbrite link via www.musselburghrfc

title: schools-planning-soft-start-new-term
story: Pupils across the county face changes as theyto school with increased emphasis on hand hygiene, staggered breaks and lunch times and no assemblies or even indoor PE initially.And they will be told to wear face masks on all home to school transport after East Lothian Council took the decision to introduce the rule across the board with exceptions for additional support learning pupils and those with medical exemptions.Primary school staff are writing to parents outlining changes to the school day which will see them asked to say goodbye to their children at school gates and youngsters barred from playing or mixing with friends in other classes initially, as they are kept in class clusters.While youngsters are not expected to social distance in schools, teaching staff will have to maintain a safe distance. In primary schools, changes include children being kept in their own class group during break times and lunch times instead of being allowed to mix with other youngsters, staggered starts and requests for parents of older children P- not to come into the playground with them in the mornings but to remain at school gates.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the youngstersrsquoto schools with a special thought for those starting school for the first time.He said: ldquoTheof pupils to school is the biggest, and most important move out of lockdown yet.ldquoGood luck to all of the countyrsquos pupils and teachers as they finally get back to face to face learning.ldquoAs a grandad with two grandchildren starting school for the first time, I am thinking especially of those new P pupils.ldquoI know that teachers, cleaners, janitors, classroom assistants and our local education department have worked incredibly hard for this day, to ensure that schools can restart safely.ldquoThey were not helped by the government telling them to plan for social distancing in the classroom, and then suddenly being told thewould be full time ndash but I have every confidence that they will have turned that round.ldquoI know that many parents will have mixed feelings, pleased that their children are going back to school, because home schooling has been tough for all families, but anxious for their childrenrsquos safety too.ldquoIt is important that everything needed is in place ndash sanitiser, testing, and, in senior years social distancing where possible. Everyone has a part to play in sticking by the rules, and I am sure that here in East Lothian, they will.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, said thewas a ldquowelcome but a watchful one.He said: ldquoIt wonrsquot be easy for either staff or pupils and care needs taken. But making a start is essential for young people and our county. Good luck and we must all do what we can to help.Headteachers at all six secondary schools have contacted parents and carers to outline a phasedwhich, instead of seeing all pupilswhen the schools officially open on Wednesday, will see them come back gradually. Five of the countyrsquos six secondary schools ndash Knox Academy, Dunbar Grammar School, North Berwick High School, Ross High School and Preston Lodge High School ndash will all follow the same phased timetable.Primary schools across East Lothian are writing to parents this week with details of how youngsters willnext week and changes to their usual routines.At Dunbar Primary School, P, P and P only attend on Wednesday, August , with only P, P and P attending on Thursday, August , with all in on Friday, August .Those pupils, parents and carers have been told on those days the soft start will mean pupils should arrive between .am to .am and instead of lining up will walk into the playground and be greeted by a member of the support staff.They will walk them into their class, then they will wash their hands under the supervision of their class teacher.Headteacher Helen Gillanders told parents: ldquoThis means that parents and pupils will need to say lsquogoodbyersquo at the main school gates rather than coming into the main playground.ldquoWe appreciate this is dferent but we are looking to manage the safety of pupils and staff and reduce the contact with adults from dferent households.Leaving times will be staggered and parents and carers asked to wait at the school gates with teachers dismissing pupils as they identy their relative.Primary  pupils at Dunbar PS will see half attend on the Wednesday and the other half on the Thursday, with a start time of am to .am and again parents and carers will be asked to say goodbye at the school gate with teaching staff taking the new pupils into class.Families are being encouraged to practise the lsquokiss and hug goodbyersquo routine with youngsters ahead of their school start date with staff on hand to support them on the day.Some primary schools, including Sandersonrsquos Wynd in Tranent, are welcoming all pupils back on Wednesday, August , with staggered times for starting and finishing their school days.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoA small number of our primary schools are operating a phased start at the beginning of the new academic session, in line with Scottish Government guidance.ldquoThe priority is to bring children back safely and to establish good hygiene protocols in our larger schools. Consideration has also been given to the transition experience for primary  pupils and for young people moving in to S.

title: renegade-street-sweepers-bid-spruce-town
story: Called the Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, it aims to meet up on a weekly basis to take on sprucing up parts of the Honest Toun by litter picking, weeding, cleaning and general tidying up.The initiative was launched following the efforts of environment group Love Musselburgh CIC whose volunteers took on the task of painting picnic tables with seats near the Promenade.Michael Philp, of Fisherrow, who set up Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, said: ldquoI set up the group to seewe could start to arrange regular volunteer work groups to go out and do little weeding jobs and tidying up the area. I thought it would be a good thing to have a separate group of people happy to help and to concentrate on what we could do as a community rather than things we canrsquot.A Facebook page was created and has already attracted more than  members.Mr Philp said he has already been out to do some weeding around a few of the benches on the Promenade, adding: ldquoI hope we can inspire others to come and help with little projects.He said: ldquoHopefully this group will grow.ldquoWe have no money or tools yet, apart from maybe tools lying in the shed or garage, but what we have is determination and passion to make change, do things together to fix and mend what might be broken.ldquoI came to Musselburgh as a child in  and itrsquos suffered like many, many towns up and down the UK with cutbacks to many services.ldquoWe can sit and talk and debate about whorsquos to blame and say who should be doing this and who should be doing that, but it doesnrsquot solve things, so I thought we could do some little bits.ldquoOthers are doing it in other local towns with great success. Irsquod like people to post up things that they feel need attention and we will seewe can get a plan together and get some things sorted.Melanie Roccio, who set up Love Musselburgh, is supporting the group.She said: ldquoIt would be great to hear from everybody about any streets or areas around town you have noticed are in need of a little bit of TLC. Is there some overgrown shrubbery that could do with being cut back, something that could do with a fresh coat of paint or some graffiti that needs cleaned To sign up for the Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, go to www.facebook groups   refshareCouncillor Andy Forrest, Depute Provost of East Lothian, said: ldquoThis is a very welcome initiative for the town which reflects the pride many local residents have for Musselburgh. The council is always keen to support such endeavours and encourage similar groups who volunteer to enhance their local environment.Fellow ward member Councillor Katie Mackie commented: ldquoItrsquos really appreciated that local residents are volunteering to help keep Musselburgh tidy. Civic pride is important and hopefully this group can supplement the routine street cleaning and waste disposal work done by East Lothian Councilrsquos hard working waste workers. Itrsquos important there is a coordinated approach between the group and the council, and I would be happy to help facilitate thisit is required.Finally, Councillor John Williamson said: ldquoThe Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers is the latest in a number of initiatives in Musselburgh which demonstrate the growing pride in our town and a determination to make it a better place for everyone. Their work tidying and weeding at the benches on the Promenade demonstrates how easy and quick it is to make a vast improvement to an area. I wish them well with their efforts in the future and hope to be able to join in myself at some point.

title: action-packed-virtual-musselburgh-festival-proves-huge-success
story: Although the election of the  Honest Lad and Honest Lass, and the festival itself, were cancelled due to the Covid- pandemic, the local community enjoyed reminiscing about past events.The Honest Tounrsquos Association, which organises the annual festival, was determined to keep the spirit of the event alive while keeping everyone safe.Two films were shown via the associationrsquos Facebook page and Twitter feed. The first, about Kirkinrsquo Sunday, was available for viewing on what would have been Kirkinrsquo Sunday ndash July . The other was about Festival Saturday, which was shown at the end of the lsquovirtualrsquo programme on July .Festival flags were delivered to local residents by association representatives to put up outside their homes ndash a gesture which may continue for future festivals.During lockdown, photos of previous festivals from the associationrsquos archives were posted on social media and this continued during lsquovirtualrsquo festival week, with popular events in the programme displayed.A virtual fancy dress parade took place, with members of the public invited to submit photos of themselves in fancy dress at home or in past parades.The virtual dog show was a roaring success, attracting more than  entries from owners who sent in photos of their pets in  classes, giving judges Gordon Vets a dficult task.Kennedy Bosworth won the most unusual place you have found your dog categoryAnother highlight was a virtual concert co-ordinated by Julie Robinson, Honest Lass . The musical extravaganza was compegravered by Caroline Grant, Honest Lass , and saw performances from the Clark Community Choir, Tutti Orchestra, Douglas McNeill, Lorraine McBrearty, Reno Di Rolloand Fiona Grant-MacDonald.Alison Elgin, president of the Honest Tounrsquos Association, said: ldquoThe virtual festival went very, very well. People enjoyed reminiscing about years gone by.ldquoThere were lots of positive and supportive comments and feedback.She added that the coronavirus lockdown had enabled the association to develop an extensive archive of old photos and videos and added that a lsquovirtualrsquo event could run alongside future festivals.

title: hairless-bikers-clocking-thousands-miles-charity
story: David Jones, , of Pencaitlandrsquos Limekilns, has joined his best friend of more than  years Trevor Kerr, , who lives in Manchester, in a trip that will see them visit as many European countries as possible.They will travel , to , miles over  days.David left for the trip on Sunday, with the pair meeting at the Channel Tunnel to go to France on Monday.He said: ldquoWe want to have fun but raise a bit of awareness and collect a bit of money along the way.The pair did not plan where they were going or where they would stay, simply booking a hotel where and when it was needed.They are former colleagues and worked together at Davidrsquos advertising company Cool Billboards Ltd, a business he sold after the death of his we Amanda to stomach cancer in February last year. Amanda had been diagnosed in November  and given  weeks to live.David and Trevor are raising money for Pancreatic Cancer UK after Trevor was diagnosed with an aggressive form of the condition in November last year,  months after Amanda.His diagnosis is terminal and he has received  chemotherapy sessions.Trevor was also given  weeks to live but chose to go through treatment to extend his le.He is receiving more treatment in September.This is not the first time that the pair have embarked on a tour like this and it was this previous trip that inspired them to go again.In Christmas , David received a present to go on a motorbike ride and the following February he left with Trevor to go on a -day tour around Europe.However, they were on their trip during the Beast from the East snowstorm of early , which saw them ride through snow in mainland Europe.David, who owns a couple of coffee shops in London, said: ldquoWe went through the Swiss Alps, France and Italy and people were following us through France and beeping their horns at us, so we said thatwe ever do this again that we must do it for charity.The pair then set up their own website, called the Hairless Bikers www.hairlessbikers, inspired by lsquoHairy Bikersrsquo David Myers and Si King with their own twist, as both David and Trevor are bald.The pair were planning their next trip until Amandarsquos terminal diagnosis, with David saying the news came ldquoall of a sudden.After Amandarsquos death, David spent time dealing and coming to terms with his loss and then Trevor received his diagnosis.And when the coronavirus pandemic started earlier this year, it added to an already dficult year.The pair were waiting for Trevor to finish his chemotherapy before starting the tour, with Trevor phoning David last month and askinghe wanted to go.David told the Courier before he set off: ldquoWersquove always said we will do it but now itrsquos all go.ldquoTrevor phoned me last weekend and said: lsquoLetrsquos just do it.rsquo If we donrsquot do it now then itrsquos never going to happen.ldquoWe thought about all of the news going on at the moment andanything happens or we need to come back we are just in Europe so can easily catch a plane home.Ahead of the trip, David said he was ldquovery excited, adding he was just going to focus on riding and see what happened.He added: ldquoWe wonrsquot stop laughing, wersquoll be like little kids.An initial target of pound was raised, with more than pound, raised in a few days.David saidan average of pound a day could be raised ldquothat will be brilliant.Donate at www.facebook donate

title: column-tory-disarray-not-reassuring
story: It cannot be reassuring for the Scottish Tories that their leader has only been in the position since February and has now left the party in disarray.It is clear the party do not hold Scottish Parliament seats in a high regard, given that it is looking likely that the next leader will be Douglas Ross, who is not even currently an MSP.Scottish Parliament seats require a member who is willing to commit time and effort to their constituency, they are not simply a stepping stone for jumping into a leadership bid.If you compare the Toriesrsquo leadership with that of Nicola Sturgeon over the last few months, with her clear and consistent messaging throughout the Covid- crisis, it is easy to see why polls for the SNP and independence are through the roof.I know that many are looking forward to enjoying the Eat Out to Help Out scheme, which will offer discounts of up to  per cent at restaurants and cafeacutes throughout August.I welcome this help for local businesses, and I am sure that this will benefit them in their restarts following lockdown.I would like to stress, however, that guidelines should always be followed within these establishments.That means that you should be socially distancing from those who are not from your household or extended household, and you should maintain good hygiene by regularly washing your hands for  seconds, as well as not touching your face.To keep yourself safe, it is important to use businesses that are taking these measures seriously and putting safety precautions in place to protect their customers.This week I will be hosting the first meeting of the Esk River Improvement Group.I look forward to working with them to make progress towards cleaning up the Esk.

title: tims-tales-mist-midges-memories
story: Oh and I forgot to mention the midges, which add a particularly Highland flavour to any camping trip up north.Such was our experience last weekend after we managed to find a campsite that was open. We managed just one overnight stay in Glen Nevis.It has always been a favourite glen of mine.Its beauty challenges the majestic Glencoe, but its landscape is gentler and less rugged, and the upper reaches of the glen take you back in time, to the majesty of the ancient Caledonian forest.In the days when I was a tour guide, I always thought that mist and rain were an essential part of a trip to the Highlands.People would refer to hot and sunny weather as good weather, but Irsquod always say that in the Highlands mist and rain can be good weather too.On such days, the weather would add the veil of mystery and unpredictability that makes the landscape so intriguing.Hardly ever was the approach to Glencoe the same because of the weather it changes the landscape in ways the imagination could never predict.Swirling mists which dress the peaks, layers of low lying cloud which suddenly break to allow sparkling rays of sunshine itrsquos spine-tinglingly magical.On days of so called good weather, when the skies were a cloudless blue, I always felt there was something missing in the experience.I know all this might sound like patter from VisitScotland attempting to persuade rain drenched tourists that they are lucky to have experienced the true mystery of our country but for me it has always been true.Of course, days of endless pelting rain are no fun and can spoil a holiday, but for me, some mist and rain, in moderation, makes a Highland holiday all the more memorable.Such was our experience last weekend, with two days that seemed to be in dferent seasons.When we arrived we were lucky to be able to put up the tent just in time, before the rain got heavy.Itrsquos always an awkward moment for me putting up our tent in full view of other campers, as we struggle to remember which pole goes where and try not to look like we need assistance.It couldrsquove been easy to be despondent at the weather. Dark brooding clouds shrouded the sides of Ben Nevis, bringing rain that threatened to dampen everything but I refused to let it dampen our spirits.I recited the famous quote: ldquoIn Scotland there is no such thing as bad weather just bad clothing.We had a hearty camp stove meal and then set off for our walk in the Nevis Gorge.Itrsquos a well kent walk now, but when I was first taken many years ago before the internet it was a relatively unknown secret. I still remember the sense of awe as I heard the roar of the river below, and the sight of the distant waterfall An Steall as we emerged from the gorge.Our trick was to go on our walk when it was raining, and after teatime so we had the place almost to ourselves, well apart from the midges.Our midge repellent was gold dust, and Irsquove always found the trick in avoiding midges is to keep moving, which we did, except for once, and we momentarily paid the price.It was a walk in the childhood footsteps of my younger self, where my young children were re-pacing along the route also taken by their older siblings years ago.It was about saying ldquohere is a place important to me, part of who I am itrsquos yours now,you want it to be.Yet not saying it with words, but by making memories that I hope will last as long as mine have.The rain and mist was all part of it, and yes even the midges. As often happens, the weather began to clear as we headed back.The sun broke through and the clouds developed a sparkling yellow tint. The mountains appeared, like giants awoken and rising to their true height.Sunshine briefly warmed our faces and it seemed a gt from the gods for our endurance.The kids danced and sang the song ldquoI can see clearly now the rain has gone as they saw a rainbow.I knew the rain hadnrsquot really gone so we didnrsquot dally.We made it back to the car, tired with sore legs, but before the next dark cloud arrived.That evening we recounted our experiences in the tent, and I told stories about the Jacobites and the old Highland way of le, and the connection to the Battle of Prestonpans on our own doorstep.The kids listened, partly because we were camping and they had no screens, so no choice but Irsquod like to believe partly also because we were in a land where stories and legends are steeped in the soil and they now felt a small part of them.It lashed with rain all night. But its rage had ended by morning and the new day welcomed us with sunshine.New adventures beckoned, with other memories to impart, on what was to become our sunny day.Loch Oich, rich in family memory and where the ashes of both my parents were scattered.Then Loch Ness, a fitting end to a pilgrimage, especially for my monster daft wee boy, and his sisters who love the mystery of the story.Such was our short ldquostaycation this summer.Wersquod followed what I have always called The Road of Legends which is the title of my yet to be published novel, an abridged version of which will be serialised on this page very soon.

title: column-tourist-home-help-love-area
story: I WAS on holiday a couple of weeks ago and on one of the days I went to the local amenity site.There I found lots of people who, like myself, were pretending that clearing out the house was the next best thing to being in some far-off beauty spot.A few days later, I went out on an early morning cycle.As I came out from Musselburgh Lagoons towards the mouth of the Esk, I saw the magnicent sight of all the seabirds, the swans and the geese gathered at that point where river meets sea.It occurred to me then that my best holiday this year could be to live in my own place as though I were a tourist.In my own hometown, I can still be awed by unexpected beauty, delighted by the simple things that sometimes familiarity overlooks.I can take time to appreciate things that normally the hurry and the care of le make miss.Maybe being a tourist at home will help me love Musselburgh and East Lothian more.As a Christian, I know that my faith is not about denying the dficulty and pain that surrounds us.People of faith look to see the possibility of Godrsquos love reaching out to them, and from them to others, when le is hardest.Living with faith is about seeing the world in a way that expects to find hope.I know that recent months have been hard for people in so many ways.But I also have heard so many people say that they have seen more clearly what is important to them and the people they love because they have needed to slow down, to live more simply, to keep closer to home.Perhaps we have an invitation to reflect on the things that we have seen in a new way over the past months, things that we have appreciated and enjoyed.Perhaps we can all find hope in a promise we make to ourselves: we will enjoy the good things we have seen around us in new ways, and to hold onto the positive changes we have made in these hard times, even when our livesto lsquonormalrsquo.

title: playparks-revamped-new-group-formed
story: A modern playpark between Seggarsdean Court and St Martinrsquos Place was completed towards the end of last month.The pound, scheme included input from youngsters in the area, who were able to choose from two designs for the park.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was keen to see the park act as an inspiration for improving other playparks in the town.She said: ldquoThe park in Neilson Park is very good but it could still be upgraded yet again.ldquoIt is quite a number of years since it was done.A potential Friends of Haddington Playparks group could look at parks throughout the town, such as those at Riverside Drive and Davidson Terrace.Mrs Wilson was keen to see the group approach Haddington and Lammermuir Area Partnership , as well as other organisations, as potential funding sources for any revamps.She encouraged fellow community councillors to think about the potential group ahead of their next meeting.Ward councillor Shamin Akhtar highlighted that there had been similar groups set up in Ormiston and Pencaitland with great success.The local authorityrsquos spokeswoman for education and childrenrsquos wellbeing vowed to liaise with those groups to seethey could offer any advice.She offered to help in ldquoany way I can and said: ldquoWe have got lots of lovely spaces around Haddington.

title: new-long-term-parking-essential-say-north-berwick-traders
story: As part of East Lothianrsquos Council Spaces for People programme to help prevent the spread of coronavirus, bollards and planters have been placed along both sides of the road, widening the pavements and removing some parking spaces, allowing pedestrians to maintain social distancing.Nearby car parks, such as Kirk Ports and The Glebe, have been turned into  or -minute stays with nounder the scheme.David Turnbull, from Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware on High Street, said North Berwick needed more long-term parking for tourists and visitors who were likely to stay for longer than  minutes.He said: ldquoThere is now an excess of short-term and a shortage of long-term parking and, whether people were for or against the putting green [Elcho Green car park], it was a way of solving long-term parking.Council plans to construct a temporary car park at Elcho Green were put on hold after more than , people signed a petition against it.David said: ldquo[Without long-stay parking, fewer] visitors and residents are going to come [to the town centre]. There is a massive shortage of long-term spaces for these kinds of people.ldquoI can see why they want to put these measures [on the east end of High Street] in place but we need more long-term parking.David said he had visited two nearby car parks that had recently been made short term on two separate occasions and they were each one third empty.And he thought much of the opposition to the Elcho Green plan was due to misinformation about what it would consist of.David said that the new parking measures on High Street had not negatively affected his business and that there was enough short-term parking for his customers.Those at gt shop Time  Tide, however, say they have not been as busy since the measures were introduced.Staff member Lorraine, who has always lived in North Berwick, said: ldquoNorth Berwick is a seaside town and is not built for this kind of traffic.ldquoA lot of people live in flats and holiday homes nearby and they used those [long-term] car parks. These have now turned into short-term parking ndash where are these people to park now Lorraine said that restricting parking on the east end of High Street affected customers who wished to purchase heavy items such as furniture, as they would be unable to carry them to a car parked further away.She added: ldquoWersquove had to do something like a lsquosmash and grabrsquo, where we watch for the person coming and quickly put the item into their car.ldquoSome people think the area is pedestrianised and are walking on the road, whereas before the cars parked on the side of the road made people realise and they were walking on the pavement.Beverly Gilhooley, owner of pet shop Barker and Bone, said business was slightly quieter than usual but the restrictions made things ldquoa little safer, adding that she thought the short-term parking should be a permanent feature in summer.She said the restrictions suited the town during the summer, when tourism was high, but not during winter.She added that the restrictions had affected deliveries to her business, which were harder to carry out, and customers who wished to purchase heavy items.Beverly said: ldquoItrsquos a brilliant idea in summer but I hope itrsquos a more temporary thing every summer.We can keep this up for a couple of months but not for any longer.The North Berwick resident said her business could afford ldquoa little hit butthe parking restrictions continued through the winter her business would not survive.Judy Lockhart, chair of North Berwick Community Council, said the group wanted to know more about the councilrsquos future plans.She said on Monday: ldquoThe community council emailed East Lothian Council on July . . . and requested a meeting to discuss Elcho Green and have since followed our request up. To date, we have not been offered any times dates by the council.

title: digging-deep-bid-secure-belhaven-bay-access
story: The stunning sandy beach and iconic Bridge to Nowhere have been enjoyed by many people for generations.However, discussions have taken place over the last few years in an attempt to find a solution which would allow people with mobility issues to cross the Biel Burn and access the golden sands.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, has been at the heart of discussions to find a way to cross the stream.On Wednesday, she was due to meet with engineering experts from Royal Haskoning.She said: ldquoThey are going to do a set of trial holes across a bit of the Biel Burn where we think a crossing will happen to determine what ground conditions are like and to seethe idea of a culvert crossing would work.ldquoThe funding was largely given to us by Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership because it is an area partnership-fostered project at this stage.ldquoThey funded the feasibility exercise but it is fantastic to be getting to some practical hole digging instead of talking about it.The trial holes will highlight what is below the surface and how easy it would be to create a new path.Currently, people visiting the picturesque bay have two choices when they step onto the beach.To cross the Biel Burn, they face wading through the water or using the Bridge to Nowhere.However, neither option is available to people with wheelchairs, buggies or mobility issues.Mrs Swan said: ldquoYou watch families with ordinary pushchairs or with an elderly relative who would love to go on the beach.ldquoChildren scamper over the bridge but the elderly relative is abandoned.ldquoIt [the new path] will be an access for all.Current plans would see a low walkway created across the burn.The new path would be visible at low tide but disappear when the water comes in, which would preserve the much-photographed sight of the bridge surrounded by water.Councillor Norman Hampshire, the local authorityrsquos spokesman for the environment, was keen to see a solution reached that would open the beach up to all.The Dunbar and East Linton ward member said: ldquoAnything that can improve access to Belhaven Bay will be a huge benefit to everybody.

title: tasty-chance-save-pounds-boosting-local-economy
story: Throughout August, customers heading to more than  businesses throughout the county can get a  per cent discount on food or non-alcoholic drinks to eat or drink ineach Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.Businesses from Whitecraig and Musselburgh in the west to Dunbar and Innerwick in the east are offering people the chance to make a saving on their bill through the Eat Out to Help Out scheme.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for tourism and economic development, stressed the importance of such promotions.He said: ldquoAt a time when we are encouraging folk to stay safe, support local and love East Lothian, Eat Out to Help Out is a great way of supporting many of the fantastic eateries we have throughout the county and doing our bit to help with East Lothianrsquos economic recovery. Food and drink and hospitality are key sectors and we are keen to promote as much expenditure as possible within the local economy, while enabling our local communities to stay safe.Iain Gray MSP welcomed the Scotland Loves Local campaign, which ties in with other campaigns supporting the lsquoshop localrsquo message, such as Love Local Business, run by the Courier, and East Lothian Councilrsquos Stay Safe, Shop Local.The coronavirus has caused ldquosignicant challenges for town centres, high streets and businesses throughout the county.Mr Gray encouraged people to get out and support them where possible.He said: ldquoOur small businesses, whether a pub, cafe, butcher, newsagent or a grocery shop, are the leblood of local economies across East Lothian.ldquoWhether itrsquos an emergency pint of milk, catching up with old friends in the local pub or having a meal close to home, our town centres have always been there for us.ldquoNow is the time for us to support them to get back on their feet, by thinking local first. Thatrsquos a sentiment Irsquove always been pleased to support and help promote, because East Lothian boasts some of the best local shops and businesses anywhere in Scotland.DOZENS of restaurants, hotels, cafes and other visitor attractions in the county, such as garden centres, have signed up to the Eat Out to Help Out scheme.Businesses which have registered for the initiative can be found online via: www.tax.service.gov.uk eat-out-to-help-out find-a-restaurantHere we list the premises taking part in East Lothian. title: trio-entrepreneurs-celebrate-receiving-25-000-cash-boost
story: Amee Ritchie and Jake Elliot Hook, former pupils of Ross High School in Tranent, set up Srsquowheat after developing the Srsquowheat bottle ndash a reusable double-ended water bottle made from a mix of plant materials.Hannah Gordon, from Ormiston, launched Crossroad Games CIC, which creates bespoke visual novel video games for business clients while co-creating alongside marginalised young people to develop their skills.They were among  student and graduate businesses at the university which received a portion of grant aid as part of a range of support from Santander Universities UK to help them through the Covid- pandemic.Hannah said: ldquoCrossroad Games, as a member of Queen Margaret Universityrsquos Business Innovation Zone, has been developing as a start-up community interest company that will co-design visual novel video games alongside marginalised young people. During the pandemic, it has become increasingly hard to see how the business would be able to keep developing for launch during a time of lockdown and uncertainty.ldquoThe Santander Universities UK funding given to Crossroad Games has allowed us to take a step forward instead of a hesitant one backwards. The funding will be going towards developing a visual novel game demo that will showcase our product offering. We are grateful to be given that opportunity by Santander and Queen Margaret University.Dr Richard Butt, the universityrsquos deputy principal, said: ldquoAt Queen Margaret University, we are proud to support student and graduate start-ups through our Business Innovation Zone, and, more broadly to support economic development.ldquoSo we thank Santander Universities for their generous support and commitment during this challenging time.

title: bus-route-extended-take-edinburgh-royal-infirmary
story: From Monday, Prentice Coachesrsquo  service will provide a direct link from the eastern side of Musselburgh to the hospital.There will be seven weekdayjourneys, setting off every hour from Seton Sands between am and pm, withjourneys from the hospital between am and pm.On a Saturday,  journeys will alternate with  journeys to provide a mostly hourly service from the hospital.This extension to the hospital service will be for a trial period to gauge customer demand.A spokesman for the Hadington-based bus firm said: ldquoService  has always been very popular with passengers but, due to being in a low fare zone, revenue was poor this added to the drop in overall passenger numbers due to Covid- has meant it has been very dficult to justy reinstating the route.ldquoWe hope the added option of travel to the Royal Infirmary will in time boost passenger numbers and then hopefully in due course we can expand the number of daily journeys.Meanwhile, a new  service is being launched on Monday. It will connect Haddington with Humbie and Elphinstone.Finally, the  service is also being altered. A change of route in Longniddry is being introduced to the service, which links Haddington with the ERI.

title: plans-revealed-transform-former-faside-lodge-site
story: East Lothian Council has revealed proposals for the site of the former Farsquoside Lodge, Tranent, which would see  cottage flats and bungalows built on the townrsquos Church Street.However, with Covid- restrictions making it dficult to host the normal public consultations which would see people go to a local centre or hall to view plans and give feedback, the council has launched it online, urging residents to get involved.The plans are described as being at the design stage and would see a mixture of mainstream and specialised housing with wheelchair access on the site with a mix of two and three-bedroom bungalows and one and two-bedroom cottage flats.Vehicle access to the new housing would be from neighbouring Elder Court and the design would follow the councilrsquos climate change strategy.Following the consultation, a planning application is expected to be lodged with the council and,approved, construction could be completed by .A council spokesperson said that the online consultation, which launched last Monday, would be open for comments and feedback until this Sunday.They said: ldquoThe councilrsquos development team would normally hold a local public consultation event to give the community an opportunity to discuss further, provide comments and raise any concerns. Due to the current situation, we are unable to hold any face-to-face events however, people can review the proposals and provide any feedback and concerns prior to the proposal being submitted to our planning department via the consultation hub.Farsquoside Lodge operated as a nursing home until October, when it was replaced by the new CrookstonCare Home in Tranent. The former building was demolished after the removal of asbestos.To get involved in the consultation, go to https:eastlothianconsultations policy-partnerships development-proposal-for-faside-lodge-tranent

title: musselburgh-primary-school-extension-gets-go-ahead
story: Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh, plans to add a new sports hall and nursery to its already-extended building as it prepares for another increase in its school rolls.The school, which was established in , moved onto its current site in , when it was officiallyopened by Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother.However, the latest extension will mean the loss of a seven-a-side football pitch on the grounds, with plans to temporarily create a second pitch two miles away to compensate.A report by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officers said that two pitches would be lost to the planned nursery extension, with only one being replaced on another part of the site.It said that a new-a-side sports pitch would be created on council-owned land at Whitecraig, two miles from the school, next to an already-established pitch which would be lsquorealignedrsquo to allow for the addition.And it revealed that, in the long term, it was expected thatnew public use facilities at Musselburgh Grammar School would provide a permanent alternative to the lost sports pitch.The report said: ldquoSportscotland have been consulted on the application and have no objection, being satisfied that loss of a seven-a-side sports pitch at Pinkie St Peterrsquos will be mitigated by the temporary provision of an -a-side sports pitch on land at Whitecraig and the subsequent provision of a permanent synthetic grass pitch at Musselburgh Grammar School.The new nursery will also be built over the current car park access, meaning a new vehicle access will need to be built off Pinkie Road, which runs alongside the school site.Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School currently has just under  children attending school and nursery.In , it was given the go-ahead to add a single-storey extension to accommodate its growing school roll, with a secondlarger extension approved the following year.The most recent application, which received no objections, will see a new sports hall to the north of the building and nursery playrooms to the east.There will also be additional car parking spaces and cycle park facilities.

title: former-butcher-shop-town-centre-sale

title: pupils-face-school-bus-ban-masks-not-worn
story: The local authority has invested pound.million on increasing the number of buses for pupils when theyto school next week.However, it has introduced a face mask rule across all its home to school transport, including taxis, private school buses and public transport.Parents have been told children should also carry hand sanitiser which they are expected to use before boarding any school transport and put on their mask every day.The council, which provides transport for , children, said , of those pupils are provided with bus passes to use public buses on the routes with the rest using school buses contracted by the local authority and private hire taxis.MORE: What day does your high school childto school  Find out hereThe face mask rule will not apply to youngsters who are exempt under the exemption rules for public transport.New guidelines state that pupils on school buses should all be travelling to the same school so shared trips are no longer allowed so some routes shared by primary and secondary children are no longer available, eventhe children are from the same family.The council said  new buses have been commissioned across contractor and public service routes to allow pupils to continue to travel safely to school at a cost of pound.million.And it said guidance is being shared with families telling them to provide their children with hand sanitiser, which must be used prior to boarding the bus and face coverings which will be mandatory on all home to school transport.The council warned: ldquoFailing to adhere to these guidelines could lead to a pupil being refused entry to the bus.Seating plans will also be introduced on buses and families will receive details of timetables when they receive their bus passes.The council said the measures had been introduced in response to the current Covid- public health emergency and would be subject to review in line with any further Scottish Government guidelines.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoI know this will be a relief for many parents who rely on our home to school transport services but who were also concerned about what this would look like in the current health emergency.ldquoOur officers have worked hard with transport partners to enable us to provide a service to families.ldquoWe are in the process of sending out bus This will be essential to the operation of the service.

title: artist-harry-king-festival-launches-shop-local-scheme
story: While festival organisers have teamed up with businesses in North Berwick to encourage residents to lsquoshop localrsquo.More than  pupils from throughout East Lothianrsquos schools submitted colourful drawings for a competition to create the programmersquos cover.Originally, the plan was for the winning entry to be used on the cover of this yearrsquos programme. However, it was announced in May that the North Berwick-based festival ndash which features top names from the world of art, comedy and literature ndash was being cancelled for  due to the coronavirus.Instead, the winning entry, which came from Harry King, a P pupil at Longniddry Primary School, will be used at next yearrsquos festival, which takes place from August -. His eye-catching lighthouse and interpretation of familiar sights around North Berwick caught the judgesrsquo attention. Said Harry: ldquoMy design was inspired by the perfect day in North Berwick - having fun at the beach with the sun shining and eating ice cream.He has also won tickets and food and drink vouchers for next yearrsquos event to the value of pound.From a shortlist of five, two runners-up will also receive a family ticket for four to one of the festivalrsquos family shows.The shortlisted entries were Meghan Kynoch Taylor, from Loretto RC Primary School, Musselburgh Kiefer Nicholson, Longniddry Primary School Domenik Blumfield, from Loretto RC Primary Schooland Lily Chater, from Longniddry Primary School .Jackie Shuttleworth, Fringe by the Sea general manager, said: ldquoIt was brilliant to receive so many entries from primary school pupils across East Lothian ndash they had clearly worked hard on their designs. We found it really tricky to choose a winner but Harryrsquos colourful picture of North Berwick stood out for its attention to detail and quirky touches.Organisers are also running a prize draw, which takes place over the planned dates this yearrsquos festival, August -, to encourage people to shop local.Shoppers who spend more than pound in several North Berwick shops can enter the prize draw with a chance of winning a pound Fringe by the Sea package, including pound worth of tickets for next yearrsquos event, pound food and drink vouchers and pound North Berwick gt vouchers.To enter, shoppers must complete a postcard from any of the participating stores and hand it in before the closing date ndash the stores will display posters featuring the shortlisted artwork from the schools competition.The stores currently taking part are: Andersonrsquos Quality Butchers, Barker  Bone, Cake Cafeacute, Coastal Kids, Emma Combe Hair, etchellip, Fingers  Thumbs Arts  Craft Centre, Heart  Sole, Meg Maitland, No  Hotel  Bistro, Rock  Bird, Scottish Seabird Centre, Steampunk Coffee, The Herringbone and Westgate Gallery.Jackie added: ldquoWe have many fantastic businesses in North Berwick and wersquore encouraging people to shop local and support the livelihoods of our traders and keep the town thriving.Those looking for a taste of the festival can enjoy a pop-up photography exhibition in the Robert Louis Stevenson garden at the far east end of High Street. The exhibitionhas been curated by local artist and filmmaker Holger Monhaupt from his own images of last yearrsquos event plus additional images of previous years. It has been designed, constructed and installed by Michael James Lewis and represents a Spiegeltent, the iconic venues used at Fringe by the Sea each year.

title: temporary-measures-introduced-tranent-aid-social-distancing
story: The measures, being introduced under East Lothian Councils Spaces for People scheme, will be monitored and changes may be madenecessary.They include a temporary introduction of a -minute parking limit in the Winton Place and Lindores Drive car parks to increase turnover and ensure visitors have spaces to park on High Street the -minute parking limit will also be introduced on Winton Place.Long-stay parking will be introduced at Foresters Park and the pedestrian crossing signals on High Street will be re-timed so the green man appears more frequently.Three parking spaces near congested footways on Bridge Street and High Street will be temporarily removed, says the council, to create more space for social distancing and queuing, something East Lothian Council says ldquowill be vital with schools ing and many pupils accessing the high street during lunch time.Most of the car parking spaces in Tranent town centre will continue to be available for use.Alongside these parking restrictions,  mile per hour speed limits will temporarily be introduced across the town alongside additional traffic calming measures.East Lothian Council says these will allow for a more flexible use of the town centre and allow it to respond to requests for the use of public space.It says the measures will also make it easier for people to cross the roadnecessary to maintain social distancing, support walking and cycling to school and enhance walking and cycling routes.The council also proposes to install electric-bike hire at Civic Square inlate autumn once the procurement process is complete.In addition, Ross High School will also be introducing staggered lunch breaks to reduce the number of pupils accessing the High Street at any one time.East Lothian Council says there was "engagement" with "key local stakeholders, including the community council, area partnership and local councillors" before all the measures were confirmed.

title: boots-open-booking-system-winter-flu-jab-service-early
story: The company say that so far, more than , people have registered with their winter flu jab service - which also aims to help relieve pressure on the NHS.According to new research comission by Boots UK,more people than ever considering a flu jab this winter, with almost a thirddoing so because they are more aware of the need to protect themselves against flu as a result of the Coronavirus pandemic.The research also round  per cent of people surveyed in the UK are more conscious about catching flu this winter than in previous years, and  per cent of people surveyed nationwide havent previously had a flu vaccination.Boots has four stores in East Lothian, two in Musselburgh and one each in Haddington and North Berwick.What have Boots said Anne Higgins, director of Pharmacy at Boots UKsaid: "As Covid- continues to be present in the UK, it is more important than ever for people to consider getting their flu vaccination."Although the flu vaccination does not prevent Covid-, both of these viruses have an impact on the respiratory system soyou can prevent flu, it can be a huge benefit to your overall health including your immune system."We also know that winter is a particularly busy time for GPs and hospitals so getting vaccinated early to protect against flu could help reduce the risk of the NHS becoming overwhelmed with both cases of flu and COVID-."Boots found that almost a quarterof people studied were unaware they can get a free NHS flu vaccination from their local pharmacythey are part of a group deemed at-risk by the NHS,saving the need to book an appointment with their GP.What safety measures will be in place In a bid to continue putting safety first, Boots has increased in-store measures to ensure all customers feel at ease when going for a vaccination.For example, customers will be asked to read key information online and where possible attend their appointment on their own to avoid any crowding in the pharmacy area.Customers will also be asked to adhere to social distancing measures in waiting areas, sanitise their hands and continue to wear a face-covering throughout their appointment.It is also advised that customers bring their own pen to complete any essential paperwork and they will be asked not to speak to the pharmacist during the actual vaccination to minimise the risk of droplet spreading.If the consultation room is small, the pharmacist may ask to keep the door open during the appointment.Whatpharmacy services are available in Boots stores The following can be accessed in store or online at Boots:How can I book an appointment Boots say that customers will be able to book their appointments online and in store within the next few days with appointments available from mid-September.To book an appointment for the Winter Flu Jab Service at Boots,visit:https:www.boots online pharmacy-services winter-flu-jab-services.
