lockdown, closely monitoring the impact of each change we make."As more parts of our society and economy reopen, it is vital we all keep in mind our personal responsibility to do the right thing and make sure we continue to protect ourselves and others from the virus.ldquoThis means keeping a two metre distance from others, washing our hands often and wearing a face mask on public transport."These are simple steps to take that benefit us all. title: changes made penarth town centre lockdown plans
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs reported in the Penarth Times on Thursday, the town councilsaid the results show ldquowidespread backing for changes.The survey, which attracted  responses, showed  per cent of people thought there should be more outdoor space for pedestrians and businesses.Seventy-five per cent thought parking arrangements needed to change, and  per cent said the town needs to ldquoprepare for the future.Some traders, who oppose the changes ndash specically a one-way traffic system around the town and making Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street a traffic free zone, have said the questions in the survey were too generalised and misleading.As a result of the survey, Penarth Town Council have proposed the following changes to the original ideas:Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and buses, with a mph speed limit.Lower Glebe Street as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and disabled bays. Other vehicles should not use Lower Glebe Street as a through road.Bus stops will remain as they are. There were concerns over the impact of a bus stop on Hickman Road for traders, due to air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.A two-way system to remain on Stanwell Road from the library to the traffic lights, to allow easy access to the bus stop on Rectory Road and to prevent congestion and ldquorat running through Hickman Road and Arcot Street. A two-way system to also remain from Windsor Road to Railway Terrace.The number of parking bays has also changed. There will now be  extra bays proposed, with  of them on Plassey Street.The leader of the town council, Cllr Rhiannon Birch, explained the findings and what happens next.ldquoEven before Covid-, town centres across the country were facing issues, including the need to modernise infrastructure, and the impact of online shopping, she said. ldquoThe current pandemic has added to the scale of the challenge.ldquoThe consultation shows that a clear majority recognise the need for a degree of change in the town centre, both for it to survive in the present and to thrive in future.ldquoThe results call for the establishment of a greater degree of safe space and proposals which increase a degree of pedestrianisation whilst also increasing parking spaces.ldquoThe results show substantial agreement on these aims. Reflecting this widespread and clear response, Penarth Town Council calls on our partners in the Vale of Glamorgan Council to embrace the results and recommendations.ldquoSpecically, Penarth Town Council believes that creating a safer environment through the closure of Windsor Road to traffic for part of the day, between Arcot Street and the roundabout, including the Lower Glebe Street, would be the best way to ensure that people can feel confident about shopping safely. It would allow safe use of the space in front of shops, bars, cafes and restaurants.ldquoIt also lessens the need for one-way systems on pavements for pedestrians, which are perplexing for many and hard to implement. These proposals can be achieved in a way which also increases the amount of parking spaces available.The results will now be put to the Vales Planning Committee for consultation.For more information, visit https:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk news survey-results Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. genres.Now residents will be able to access further facilities as the use of PCs and the physical browsing of books is permitted again.Initially, PCs can be booked for a -minute period once a week, with the number available reduced to allow for appropriate social distancing.Fixed time limits will also mean staff can properly sanitise machines between uses.MORE STORIESVale of Glamorgan libraries offer click and collect serviceBarry library closes in wake of coronavirus concernsVale Libraries lockdown Lit Facebook group established for book-loversIt will also be possible to secure a -minute slot to browse and select books from the libraries, with strict restrictions on the number of people admitted to the buildings at any one time.Library members can make appointments for either of these services by phone.Vale council cabinet member for education and regeneration, Cllr Lis Burnett said: ldquoWe know what a vital role our libraries play in the lives of some of our residents, especially at a time when most are spending more time at home.ldquoReading in particular is a productive and stimulating way to fill time so Irsquom delighted that we are now able to make more of our library services available again.ldquoWhile increasing numbers of people have been accessing books, resources and activities online, for many the reopening of library buildings will be very welcomelsquoOur library staff have worked hard to provide as many facilities as possible online, but I know they are looking forward to seeing familiar faces and hopefully some new ones too.ldquoResidents will be able to use PCs and visit libraries in person to browse books though both activities will be tightly controlled.ldquoSafety remains the number one priority and all appropriate measures will be in place to protect both library members and staff.During this period, chairs will be removed from the libraries to discourage sitting, toilets will be closed to the public and there will be no meetings, activities or room bookings available.Anyone entering the building will be asked to use hand gel and complete a track and trace card giving their name and contact details.Library staff will work behind protective screens when at a desk and wear visors at other times and all books will be quarantined for  hours before being cleaned and put back into circulation.Current weekday opening times will remain the same initially, with Barry and Cowbridge operating from am to pm and pm to pm, and Llantwit Major open for the second of those periods.The Libraries will also open between am and pm on Saturdays.As building improvement work is shortly due to take place at Penarth Library, that will not open in the same way as the councilrsquos other libraries.However, it will continue to offer a phone and internet click-and-collect service, as will Barry, Cowbridge and Llantwit Major.Community libraries in Rhoose, St Athan and Sully are also offering a click-and-collect service, with Dinas Powys and Wenvoe likely to join them in the near future.Some other council services will also be available face to face at the Civic Offices on an appointment basis from Monday, August .Appointments s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentICONIC buildings and venues across Wales will light up in red as part of a UK-wide day of action highlighting the urgent government help the sector needs during the covid- crisis.The live events industry across the UK will come together, at pm on Tuesday, August  to host a series of creative action to help save the live events and entertainment sector which is on the verge of collapsing without financial support from the government.Hundreds of venues are expected to turn their lights red in more than  cities across the UK to symbolise the industry going into Red Alert.In Wales, in excess of  venues and events businesses have signed up to turn red to stress the need for support.MORE STORIESWelsh Government aims to secure the future of Wales culture sectorWales Millennium Centre in Cardf Bay will close until at least January The show must go on - says owner of Waless smallest theatre, The Small Space, BarryA large collective from the industry made up of trade bodies, businesses, freelancers and venue staff, currently on furlough, will gather in groups of no more than in front of each venue to support the #WeMakeEvents #LightItInRed campaign.Wales-based events companies will light up their trucks as they lay empty on forecourts.Welsh venues confirmed to turning red are the Motorpoint Arena, Cardf Castle, Principality Stadium, City Hall, Wales Millennium Centre, New Theatre, Chapter, St Davidrsquos Hall, venues in Womanby Street, USW Atrium, Dolman Theatre, ICC Wales.Sarah Hemsley-Cole, director of SC Productions Ltd, an events production company based in Cardf said: ldquoCovid- has had a devastating effect on the live events and arts sector here in Wales, not only our theatres, but our touring shows, stadium shows, live music venues and outdoor arts have been decimated by the pandemic.ldquoThe ecosystem of our creative industry ndash skilled professional such as technicians, designers, actors, performers, musicians and suppliers are now fighting for survival."In Wales alone there are in excess of  iniduals employed within the creative industries, and with the governments furlough scheme ending in October, and with no sense of a time line when events and venues can re-open ndash many are being forced in to poverty debt and despondency.ldquoWith no timeline or criteria having been issued by the Welsh Government for their administration of the cultural recovery fund, unlike the Welsh Arts Council who have released their timeline for applications, this delay will leave the whole industry extremely vulnerable and at risk of extinction.ldquoWe urgently need the financial support across the creative industries extended, we need support now in order to support anyone and everyone from falling through the cracks, and we need grants not loans for the supply chain.ldquoAll live events, including sporting events, provide both a massive part of many peoplersquos social calendar and a huge amount of employment.ldquoThe call to action hopes to raise awareness for over a million professionals at risk of losing their jobs, , of whom deliver outdoor events, around  per cent of the workforce are freelance.ldquoThe imminent closure of the self-employed income support scheme at the end of the month threatens their livelihood.ldquoUnlike other industries, events, festivals, and performances have been unable to safely reopen due to social distancing guidance and may not reopen until early  ndash and opening times keep being pushed back.ldquoWith no government support on the horizon for the event supply chain, redundancies have already begun, research indicates that  per cent of companies will have served redundancy notices by end of August, this rises to  per cent by the end of December.Cardf Motorpoint Arena managing director, Phil Sheeran added: ldquoThis isnrsquot just about our venues and the staff specically associated with them.ldquoNor just about the companies directly involved in live events.ldquoThis is also about the hotels and their staff where fans stay pre and post concerts.ldquoRestaurants, bars and pubs where for lots of concert goers the evening begins.ldquoTaxis, bus companies, trains and even airlines.ldquoProbably every business in a city like Cardf benefits in some way or another from the economic impact of the live events industry at whatever venue size you can think of.ldquoThe risk is huge for many, many people and sectors.ldquoWe need to get back to work without restrictions.ldquoIf that cannot happen then the support mechanisms like furlough, grants ndash not loans, and an extension to the self-employment scheme must be continued.More details can be found on the event Facebook page Wales - We Make Events   https:www.plasa.org we-make-events Also, tweet #newtheatrecardf and Facebook @newtheatrecdf article_url   content_id   site_id story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityLocal authorities across Scotland are taking dferent approaches with the time frame for reopening for the first time since March .Pupils in the Scottish Borders are ing on Tuesday, as are some in Shetland on a phased basis.Alex Bisset, an S pupil at Kelso High School, in the Scottish Borders, told the PA news agency he felt safe ing as extra hygiene measures have been put in place on campus.But he is pessimistic about how long the school will remain open.The -year-old from Birgham said: ldquoIrsquom feeling quite happy that things are slowly ing to normal but at the same time I donrsquot think itrsquos going to last.ldquoI feel like in not too long therersquos going to be perhaps another outbreak and wersquoll all be sent home again. vw,vw,px, px"Pupils arrive at Kelso High School Isla Findlay, an S pupil at the school, said she felt a little overwhelmed seeing so many of her classmates after five months of lockdown.The -year-old from Kelso said: ldquoIrsquom a bit nervous but, yeah, it will be good.ldquoItrsquos just, like, whatrsquos going to be dferent  Irsquom happy to see all of my friends ndash just how are they going to handle everything  Itrsquos a bit scary.ldquoIrsquom feeling safe, itrsquos just a lot seeing everyone again. I thought it would be a lot worse but itrsquos nice to see everyone as itrsquos been so long.Kelso High School head teacher Jill Lothian is optimistic about theof pupils, saying she does not want the pandemic to ldquodefine them.But she acknowledged some parents are worried about the move. vw,vw,px, px"Pupils arrive at Kelso High School on the Scottish Borders She said: ldquoThey came in this morning, they were smiling, it was great to see them in school and I hope theyrsquore glad to be back ndash itrsquos about learning.ldquoWhat I donrsquot want is for Covid to define them and I think thatrsquos whatrsquos really important is that we take this opportunity this year and move forward ndash and thatrsquos what wersquoll help them with.Parent council chairwoman Gemma OrsquoBrien, who has a daughter at the school, said: ldquoIrsquom nervous for the students, theyrsquove been cooped up for the last five months with their family and now the day has come where theyrsquore just getting back into school with all of their old friends and new friends as well and all their teachers.ldquoItrsquos a massive step just to get here and I think a lot of them were not sure when it was going to come andit was ever going to come this year.ldquoIrsquom a little bit apprehensive for everybody but I know this is what everybody is needing.Elsewhere in Scotland pupils willfrom Wednesday, with many councils operating a phasedahead of the August  deadline for all pupils to be back full-time. vw,vw,px, px"First Minister Nicola Sturgeon inspects preparations during a visit to West Calder High School in West Lothian Social distancing will be in place for adults and encouraged for older pupils, while young children will not be expected to.Face masks will only have to be worn by staff who cannot effectively social distance, however anyone who wishes to should be allowed.Fears have been raised about how well-prepared teachers are to deal with mitigating the spread of the virus, as well as anxiety among staff who are ing.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said schools ing is a ldquomajor milestone in the fight against coronavirus in Scotland.She added: ldquoTodayrsquoshas been made possible by the progress all of us have made in suppressing the virus but we know from all sorts of evidence here at home and where across the UK and across Europe that progress remains fragile and we all really need to continue to be vigilant and cautious.Some parents may view theof schools as a way for them to get back into their workplace, she said, but urged them to work from homepossible as it is ldquosafest. vw,vw,px, px"EIS general secretary Larry Flanagan voiced concerns about safety Educational Institute of Scotlandgeneral secretary Larry Flanagan said about % of its members had expressed ldquodeep concerns about safety over the reopening of schools.He told BBC Good Morning Scotland: ldquoOne of the areas that is of particular concern is around the absence of physical title: traffic disruption expected two psk ni road schemes start
story: Concern as  dogs put to sleep across NIArmed men wearing face masks rob NI jewellery storeNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsTraffic disruption expected as two £k NI road schemes to startTwo £k resurfacing schemes for parts of Co Armagh are start this week with traffic disruptions expected.By Carmel RobinsonTuesday, th August , : am""The schems include two contracts, one in Mowhan Road, Markethill costing £k and another in Laurelvale, Tandragee costing £k.Newry and Armagh DUP MLA William Irwin and Independent Cllr Paul Berry both welcomed the schemes.Mr Irwin said, “This is fantastic news for road users and residents of Markethill and the surrounding area and I understand that work is due to commence on Mowhan Road Markethill on Monday  August  with the work extending  kilometres from its junction with the Cladymilltown Road to just south of the Tullyallen Road junction.”Paul BerryHe added. “Access for residents will be maintained at all times however it will be closed to through traffic from th August to th September between the hours of am and pm Monday – Friday and ersions will be signposted. Officials state that the road will be open to traffic in the evenings during the week and all day on Saturday and Sunday.”He added, “It is also great to see work commencing in Laurelvale and Mullavilly with an investment of close to £,. A closure scheme in a similar manner will see the road closed from Monday  August to Friday  September between the hours of .am and .pm and access maintained for residents throughout the works phase and the roads will be open outside of construction hours.”He added, “When both sets of works are combined this represents a signicant investment locally in the constituency. The roads in question will certainly benefit from this work and in both instances the surfaces have been slowly deteriorating over time.”“Whilst there will be iniably disruption to traffic flow during the works, it will be a worthwhile scheme to ensure that the road surfaces in both locations are maintained to the standards expected and I thank Transport NI for this investment.”William Irwin MLAMr Berry said roads in the Mullavilly Road area of Laurelvale had been in a ‘dreadful state’ for a long time.He said: “I have lobbied Infrastructure NI for few years now and kept in close contact to ensure that the main street and a section of road from the bus shelter and footpaths be resurfaced. That section of road has been in dreadful state for a long time and the water gathered along the road, so drainage is key. There is also a need to look again at the current ramps as they are in over  years now and need redesigned. Obviously there is going to be traffic disruption over the next number of weeks but long term these road improvements will be great long term for the Village.”A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Stolen car used in ram-raid attack on shopRestaurant which provides employment for young people with special needs closes its doorsNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . story: Attempted theft condemnedArmed men wearing face masks rob NI jewellery storeNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleCampaign to raise funds for puppy Kiro’s le-saving operationHe is just five months old and a typical exhuberant puppy but Kiro has been diagnosed with serious genetic condition which could mean a short le full of agony.By Carmel RobinsonMonday, th August , : pm""An Alaskan Malamute, Kiro is a large puppy, full of energy and has become a vital part of the Goff household in Co Armagh.Christopher Goff, who lives with his family in Magheralin near Lurgan, explained how the family adopted Kiro in March from a woman in Belfast and he became a close part of their family.A full time carer for his mum Carmel, Christopher said the puppy had lted the family’s spirits, particularly since COVID- Lockdown as they had to shield due to his mother’s illness. Kiro.“Kiro has given us such respite. He is such a great puppy. He loves walking and is very happy. We couldn’t understand it when we heard clicking sounds on his hips,” said Christopher.He said when they visited the owner of the pups, they saw the puppy’s mother and were assured by the woman they had bought Kiro from that both were in good health. “They all looked to be in good health,” said Christopher.He explained that they took him to the vet for his first injections. “The vet stretched his hips and said everything was Ok,” said Christopher.Kiro“We became concerned as he was starting to ‘bunny hop’ when he was running andwe picked him up he would yelp,” he said.They took Kiro back to the same veterinary surgery for the second set of injections. Christopher said they were told that everything was good.But two weeks ago they noticed his hips were ‘clicking’.This time they went to a vets in Lurgan who said they could feel Kiro’s hips were ‘pretty bad’.“He has Canine Juvenile Hip Dysplasia and it is pretty bad,” said Christopher.The -year-old who isn’t working and is a full time carer for his mother and father, said they had taken out pet insurance but sadly it was not enough cover for this particular condition.He explained that it is a genetic condition and rectying it with a double hip replacement is going to cost around £k. Already they have managed to raise £,.“To give you an idea of how bad his case is, our vet explained that the worst case scenario would be a score of , where malamutes usually sit at around a .. Kiro’s hip scores are a .. This means he will require two hip replacements pretty much as soon as possible.“We understand it’s a dficult time to be asking for donations, and this is a last resort for us. “Our aim is to raise enough funds to get Kiro a double total hip replacement which would give him a new lease of le. “However,we aren’t able to raise enough funds for this, we will be using the money to give Kiro a double partial hip replacement which will help to signicantly reduce his pain. “Our vet also explained to us that by the time he is two years old, his condition will have worsened, therefore it is important we are able to give him the care he needs as soon as possible.”If you would like to help check out the Go Fund Me page here https:www.gofundme f kiros-hip-replacements utm_sourcecustomerutm_mediumcopy_linkutm_campaignp_cf+share-flow-fbclidIwARpDXrMFqgiBCOaISkLOKBos_YVaGicl_YbRFBEIpWJRHJOMYLrkA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
